revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox military person |name=Francis William Fellowes Lukis |image=014355Lukis.jpg |caption=Group Captain Frank Lukis during World War II |birth_date={{birth date|1896|7|27|df=yes}} |death_date={{death date and age|1966|2|18|1896|7|27|df=yes}} |birth_place=[[Balingup, Western Australia|Balingup]], Western Australia |death_place=[[Melbourne]] |nickname="Luke" |allegiance=Australia |branch=[[Royal Australian Air Force]] |serviceyears=1914–46 |rank=[[Air Commodore]] |unit=[[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron AFC]] (1917–18) |commands=[[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] (1925–30)
[[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]] (1930, 1932–34)
[[No. 1 Aircraft Depot RAAF|No. 1 Aircraft Depot]] (1936–38)
[[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]] (1939–41)
[[Northern Area Command (RAAF)|Northern Area Command]] (1941–42)
[[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Area Command]] (1942)
[[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 Operational Group]] (1943–44)
[[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]] (1944–45)
[[Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|Eastern Area Command]] (1945–46) |battles=World War I *[[Middle Eastern theatre of World War I|Middle Eastern theatre]] *[[Sinai and Palestine Campaign]] World War II *[[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]] *[[New Britain campaign]] |awards=[[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]]
[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (2) |laterwork= Manager, [[Australian National Airways|ANA]] (1946–57) }} [[Air Commodore]] '''Francis William Fellowes (Frank) Lukis''', [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (27 July 1896 – 18 February 1966) was a senior commander in the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF). A veteran of World War I, he first saw combat as a soldier in the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] at [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]]. In 1917, Lukis transferred to the [[Australian Flying Corps]] and flew with [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]] in the [[Middle Eastern theatre of World War I|Middle East]], where he was twice [[mentioned in despatches]]. A member of the Australian Air Corps following the war, he transferred to the fledgling RAAF in 1921, and became the first Commanding Officer of the newly re-formed [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] at [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales, in 1925. Lukis went on to lead No. 1 Squadron in the early 1930s, and was promoted to [[group captain]] in 1938. Appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] the same year, he was in charge of [[RAAF Williams#Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]], Victoria, during the early years of World War II. He later held forward commands in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific theatre]], including [[Northern Area Command (RAAF)|Northern Area]] (later [[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Area]]), for which he was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]], and [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 Operational Group]] (later [[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]]). Lukis also served on the Air Board, the RAAF's controlling body, as [[Air Member for Personnel (Australia)|Air Member for Personnel]]. After retirement from the Air Force in 1946, he became a manager with [[Australian National Airways]], and was active in veterans' associations. He died in 1966 at the age of sixty-nine. ==Early life and World War I== [[File:B01238Lukis1918.jpg|thumb|left|240px|Lieutenant Lukis (middle row, fourth left) with officers of No. 1 Squadron of the Australian Flying Corps in front of a Bristol Fighter, Palestine, November 1918|alt=Twenty-five uniformed men standing or seated in front of a biplane with a four-bladed propeller]] Born on 27 July 1896 in [[Balingup, Western Australia|Balingup]], Western Australia, Frank Lukis was the son of [[Pastoral farming|grazier]] William Fellowes Lukis and his wife Jean. He was educated at [[Hale School|The High School]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], and later worked on the family farm.Ritchie, ''Australian Dictionary of Biography'', pp. 135–136 In October 1914, he joined the [[First Australian Imperial Force|Australian Imperial Force]] as part of the [[10th Light Horse Regiment (Australia)|10th Light Horse Regiment]], the only such regiment raised in Western Australia.[http://www.aif.adfa.edu.au:8080/showPerson?pid=181268 Francis William Fellowes Lukis] at [http://www.aif.adfa.edu.au:8080/index.html The AIF Project]. Retrieved on 18 February 2009.[http://www.awm.gov.au/units/unit_10567.asp 10th Light Horse Regiment] at [[Australian War Memorial]]. Retrieved on 10 December 2009. Ranked [[corporal]], Lukis sailed from [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]] aboard A47 ''Mashobra'' on 17 February 1915, seeing combat first at [[Gallipoli Campaign|Gallipoli]] and then in Egypt. At Gallipoli, the 10th Light Horse went into action in the [[Battle of the Nek|Battles of the Nek]] and [[Battle of Hill 60 (Gallipoli)|Hill 60]], before being withdrawn in December and redeployed to Egypt. There it took part in the campaign against the Turks in [[Sinai Peninsula|Sinai]], including the [[Battle of Romani]]. Lukis was commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] in July 1916 and promoted to [[lieutenant]] in December. On 25 February 1917, he transferred to the [[Australian Flying Corps]] (AFC) and was posted to [[No. 1 Squadron RAAF|No. 1 Squadron]] (also known until 1918 as No. 67 Squadron, [[Royal Flying Corps]]), operating in [[Sinai and Palestine Campaign|Sinai and Palestine]].Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 9 He undertook reconnaissance missions as an observer in [[Royal Aircraft Factory B.E.2]]s from April to September 1917.Cutlack, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/9/chapters/06.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', p. 71] In January 1918 he completed pilot training and began flying fighter and ground attack sorties in [[Bristol F.2 Fighter|Bristol Fighters]].Stephens, ''The RAAF in the Southwest Pacific Area'', pp. 37–39Cutlack, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/9/chapters/09.pdf ''The Australian Flying Corps'', pp. 116–117] He was twice [[mentioned in despatches]] for distinguished service with the AFC in the Middle East, the first [[London Gazette|gazetted]] on 16 January 1918, and the second on 12 January 1920.{{LondonGazette|issue=30480|supp=yes|startpage=929|endpage=937|date=16 January 1918|accessdate=on 12 September 2011}}{{LondonGazette|issue=31728|supp=yes|startpage=500|endpage=507|date=12 January 1920|accessdate=on 12 September 2011}} Lukis finished the war a [[Flight (military unit)|flight commander]] with the temporary rank of [[Captain (land)|captain]], and returned to Australia on 5 March 1919. ==Between the wars== {{stack|[[File:LukisRichmond1925.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Flight Lieutenant Lukis (far left) and members of No. 3 Squadron, RAAF Richmond, 1925|alt=Four men, each wearing a flying helmet and goggles]]}} With the disbandment of the wartime AFC, Lukis joined the short-lived Australian Air Corps early in 1920.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', pp. 17–20 He transferred to the newly formed [[Royal Australian Air Force]] in March the following year. Ranked [[flying officer]] (honorary [[flight lieutenant]]), he was one of the original twenty-one officers on the Air Force's strength at its formation, and became popularly known as "Luke".Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/01.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 16] In February 1922, he surveyed the air route between Perth and [[Port Augusta, South Australia|Port Augusta]], South Australia.Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 54 He took part in one of the embryonic service's earliest public flying displays in May that year, when he and another pilot flew [[Airco DH.9]]s in mock [[dogfight]]s with four [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5]]s during the New South Wales Aerial Pageant at [[Victoria Park, Sydney]].Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 45 On 21 January 1925, he married Florence St Aubyn Allen at St Mary's Anglican Church, West Perth; the couple later had two sons. The previous year, Lukis had been best man at the wedding of Squadron Leader [[Frank McNamara (VC)|Frank McNamara]], the AFC's only [[Victoria Cross]] recipient in World War I.Coulthard-Clark, ''A Hero's Dilemma'', p. 68 [[No. 3 Squadron RAAF|No. 3 Squadron]] was re-formed at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Point Cook Base|RAAF Point Cook]], Victoria, on 1 July 1925, with Lukis as its [[Commanding Officer]] (CO). Over the next week, operating DH.9s and S.E.5s, the unit established itself at the Air Force's newest base, [[RAAF Base Richmond|RAAF Station Richmond]], New South Wales.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 21–23, 123 Alerted to a forthcoming inspection by the [[Chief of Air Force (Australia)|Chief of the Air Staff]], Group Captain [[Richard Williams (RAAF officer)|Richard Williams]], Lukis had the foresight to engage in a speedy beautification program at the base, arranging delivery of pot plants and shrubs; the notoriously fastidious Williams concluded the inspection by pronouncing himself "happily surprised ... that so much had been done so quickly".Coulthard-Clark, ''The Third Brother'', p. 136 For the duration of his tour as No. 3 Squadron commander, Lukis doubled as CO of the base. He was promoted [[squadron leader]] on 2 July 1927, and handed over command to Squadron Leader [[Harry Cobby]] on 13 January 1930. Lukis served as CO of No. 1 Squadron from 1930 to 1934, interrupted in 1931 by a posting to Britain to attend [[RAF Staff College, Andover]]. Raised to [[Wing Commander (rank)|wing commander]], he was placed in charge of [[No. 1 Aircraft Depot RAAF|No. 1 Aircraft Depot]] at [[RAAF Williams#RAAF Williams Laverton Base|RAAF Station Laverton]], Victoria, in 1936.RAAF Historical Section, ''Units of the Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 144–145 He held command of [[No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF|No. 1 Flying Training School]] at Point Cook from January 1938 to November 1939, receiving appointment as an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] in the 1938 [[Queen's Birthday Honours|King's Birthday Honours]], and promotion to [[group captain]] in July the same year.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', p. 295{{LondonGazette|issue=34518 |supp=yes|startpage=3696|date=7 June 1938|accessdate=on 18 February 2009}} ==World War II== [[File:013177LukisCobby1940.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|Air Commodore Lukis (centre) hands over North-Eastern Area Command to Group Captain [[Harry Cobby]] (right) in August 1942|alt=Half length portrait of three military men behind a desk, all with pilot's wings on left breast pocket. One of the men, seated, has a large dark moustache and is wearing a dark winter uniform. The other two, standing on either side of the seated figure, wear short-sleeved tropical uniforms; one of them has a small moustache, the other has a holster on his belt and is clean-shaven and smoking a pipe]] The CO of RAAF Station Laverton from December 1939, Lukis was made acting [[air commodore]] and posted to [[Townsville, Queensland|Townsville]], Queensland, on 8 May 1941 as the inaugural [[Air Officer Commanding]] [[Northern Area Command (RAAF)|Northern Area]].Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/05.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 92]Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', pp. 291, 295 Described by Major General [[Lewis H. Brereton]], commander of the US [[Far East Air Force (United States)|Far East Air Force]], as "a dark, husky, energetic man with a keen sense of humour" who was very much "alive to the situation",Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/14.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 298]Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/08.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 184–185] Lukis was in charge of air defence for the north coast of Australia. His task was complicated by the poor standard and quantity of available equipment, with only [[CAC Wirraway]]s as fighters. In January 1942, Northern Area was split into [[North-Western Area Command (RAAF)|North-Western Area]] and [[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Area]], Lukis remaining in charge of the latter as a temporary air commodore. The following month, he warned higher command of the poor state of preparedness and low morale of [[Australian Army]] troops at [[Port Moresby]], New Guinea, due to lack of air cover and apparent lack of interest from government echelons. In March, seventeen [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk|P-40 Kittyhawks]] of [[No. 75 Squadron RAAF|No. 75 Squadron]], newly formed under North-Eastern Area Command, were deployed; the unit would shortly distinguish itself in the [[Battle of Port Moresby]].Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/08.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 447–448,458–462]Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 139–141 By the end of April 1942, Lukis' forces consisted of three squadrons (general purpose, transport, and fighter) at Townsville, one general purpose squadron at [[RAAF Base Amberley|RAAF Station Amberley]] in southern Queensland, and four squadrons (three general purpose and one fighter) at Port Moresby.Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', p. 299 Posted to RAAF Headquarters, Melbourne, as Air Member for Personnel, he handed over command of North-Eastern Area to Group Captain (later Air Commodore) Harry Cobby on 25 August.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/28.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 588]Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', pp. 293–295 On 23 March 1943, Lukis was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for the "courage, enterprise and devotion" that he had displayed at North-Eastern Area.{{LondonGazette|issue=35954|supp=yes|startpage=1413|date=23 March 1943|accessdate=on 18 February 2009}}[http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/awm192/00317/003170590.pdf Recommendation for Francis William Fellowes Lukis to be awarded a Commander of the Order of the British Empire] at Australian War Memorial. Retrieved on 18 February 2009. As Air Member for Personnel, he occupied a seat on the Air Board, the RAAF's controlling body that was chaired by the Chief of the Air Staff.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 52 In this position he clashed with Group Officer [[Clare Stevenson]], Director of the [[Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force]], over plans to reduce the number of female officers in technical roles. Stevenson was forced to apologise to Lukis for going over his head to the Deputy Chief of the Air Staff to voice her opposition to the scheme; nevertheless, cuts to these positions did not eventuate.Thomson, ''The WAAAF in Wartime Australia'', pp. 218–220 [[File:VIC1447LukisStevenson1943.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Lukis (right of centre) as Air Member for Personnel, with [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] (left of centre) and Group Officer [[Clare Stevenson]] (centre) before a WAAAF Guard of Honour in Melbourne, 1943|alt=Two rows of women in dark military uniforms facing each other, with a number of other military personnel and one civilian walking between them]] In November 1943, Lukis took over [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 Operational Group]] (No. 9 OG), the RAAF's main mobile formation in the Pacific at the time, after its commander, Air Commodore [[Joe Hewitt (RAAF officer)|Joe Hewitt]], was sacked by the Chief of the Air Staff, Air Vice Marshal [[George Jones (RAAF officer)|George Jones]], over allegations of poor discipline and morale.Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 122–123Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/06.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 102–103] The change in leadership dismayed the US-led [[South West Pacific Area (command)|South West Pacific Area Command]], whose senior air officers, Lieutenant General [[George Kenney]] and Major General [[Ennis Whitehead]], did not hold Lukis in the same high regard that they did his predecessor. For the next two months, No. 9 OG supported the [[New Britain campaign|Allied invasion of New Britain]]. On 17 January 1944, Lukis mounted an operation with a force of seventy-three aircraft comprising [[Bristol Beaufort]] light bombers and Kittyhawk and [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfire]] fighters, which was the largest strike undertaken by the Australians to that date. However it encountered no opposition, and Lukis voiced his concerns to Whitehead that the "mopping up" role he had been assigned was costing his fighter pilots the opportunity to engage in air-to-air combat.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/08.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 129–130] As the Pacific conflict shifted further north, No. 9 OG's operational tasking lessened and it became colloquially known in the RAAF as the "Non-Ops Group". When ordered to transfer one of his fighter wings, [[No. 73 Wing RAAF|No. 73]], to the [[Admiralty Islands campaign|Admiralty Islands]] for convoy escort in late February, Lukis complained directly to Kenney that it was a waste of resources, but was over-ruled.Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/11.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 170–171] The rest of No. 9 OG became a garrison force in New Guinea, and was renamed [[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]] on 11 April 1944 to better reflect this new status; its original mobile strike role was taken over by No. 10 Operational Group (later the [[Australian First Tactical Air Force]]).Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 144, 168Odgers, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/27/chapters/12.pdf ''Air War Against Japan'', pp. 182–183,198–200] Lukis was again considered for the position of Air Member for Personnel when the incumbent, acting Air Vice Marshal [[Adrian Cole (RAAF officer)|Adrian Cole]], was removed from his position following accusations of drunkenness at an RAAF Headquarters meeting in November 1944.Helson, [http://unsworks.unsw.edu.au/vital/access/services/Download/unsworks:3230/SOURCE02?view=true ''Ten Years at the Top'', pp. 187–190] In the event, Lukis remained in charge of Northern Command. The following April, he took command of No. 2 Training Group in Melbourne, and held this post for the remainder of the Pacific War.Gillison, [http://www.awm.gov.au/cms_images/histories/26/chapters/02.pdf ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p.36]Ashworth, ''How Not to Run an Air Force!'', pp. 303–304 ==Later life== Lukis took up his final RAAF posting, as Air Officer Commanding [[Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|Eastern Area]], in December 1945.{{cite web|author=Eastern Area Headquarters|title=Operations Record Book|series=RAAF Unit History Sheets|date=1942–45|publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]]|location=Canberra|url=http://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ViewImage.aspx?B=1359528|page= 1075|accessdate=8 August 2015}}[http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1205030 Lukis, Francis William Fellowes] at [http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/ World War 2 Nominal roll]. Retrieved on 8 August 2015. With the end of hostilities, he was summarily retired along with a number of other senior commanders and veterans of World War I, ostensibly to make way for the advancement of younger and equally capable officers.Helson, ''Ten Years at the Top'', p. 234Stephens, ''The Royal Australian Air Force'', pp. 179–181 According to RAAF historian Alan Stephens, the Air Board believed that Lukis "had not taken a role commensurate with his seniority during the war, a strange accusation to make against a man who had been Air Member for Personnel and AOC of the RAAF's most important operational group in the Southwest Pacific Area". He was officially discharged on 2 May 1946. Employed by [[Australian National Airways]] (ANA) after leaving the Air Force, Lukis become airfield manager at [[Essendon Airport|Essendon]], Melbourne. He took over the airline's [[Canberra]] office in 1952, before joining a stockbroking firm in 1957, the year that ANA merged with [[Ansett Australia|Ansett Airways]] to become Ansett-ANA. Active in veterans' organisations, he served as president of the Air Force Association in Victoria during 1947–48, and helped found the [[Commonwealth Club (Australia)|Commonwealth Club]] in Canberra in 1954. Survived by his wife and children, Frank Lukis died in Melbourne of cancer on 18 February 1966, and was cremated.[http://www.gabr.net.au/biogs/ABE1020b.htm#related Ansett-ANA (1957–1968)] at [http://www.gabr.net.au/gabr_home.html Guide to Australian Business Records]. Retrieved on 7 December 2009. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== {{Commons category|Frank Lukis}} * {{cite book | year = 2000| title = How Not to Run an Air Force! The Higher Command of the Royal Australian Air Force During the Second World War: Volume 1| url = http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/241/How-Not-To-Run-An-Air-Force-Volume-1.aspx| last = Ashworth | first=Norman| publisher = RAAF Air Power Studies Centre | location = Canberra | isbn =0-642-26550-X}} *{{cite book|last= Coulthard-Clark | first= Chris | year=1997| title= McNamara VC: A Hero's Dilemma |location=Canberra|publisher=Air Power Studies Centre|isbn=0-642-26500-3}} *{{cite book|last=Coulthard-Clark| first=Chris|year=1991| title=The Third Brother| location=North Sydney| publisher=[[Allen & Unwin]]|isbn=0-04-442307-1}} *{{cite book|last=Cutlack | first=F.M.| origyear=1923|year=1941| title=The Official History of Australia in the War of 1914–1918 (11th edition): Volume VIII – The Australian Flying Corps in the Western and Eastern Theatres of War, 1914–1918 | location=Sydney| publisher=[[Angus & Robertson]]|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1069925/|oclc=220900299}} *{{cite book|last=Gillison | first=Douglas |year=1962| title=Australia in the War of 1939–1945: Series Three (Air) Volume I – Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942 | location=Canberra| publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070209/|oclc=2000369}} *{{cite thesis | degree =Ph. D| author = Helson, Peter | title = Ten Years at the Top | publisher = [[University of New South Wales]] | location=Sydney|year = 2006 | url = http://handle.unsw.edu.au/1959.4/38729|oclc=225531223}} *{{cite book|last=Odgers | first=George | authorlink=George Odgers | origyear=1957| year=1968| title=Australia in the War of 1939–1945: Series Three (Air) Volume II – Air War Against Japan 1943–1945 | location=Canberra| publisher=Australian War Memorial|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070210/|oclc=246580191}} *{{cite book|author=RAAF Historical Section|year=1995|title=Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: A Concise History. Volume 1: Introduction, Bases, Supporting Organisations |location=Canberra| publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|isbn=0-644-42792-2}} *{{cite book|last=Roylance| first=Derek|year=1991| title=Air Base Richmond| location=RAAF Base Richmond| publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|isbn=0-646-05212-8}} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan| editor-last=Ritchie|editor-first=John|year=2000| title=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]: Volume 15| chapter=Lukis, Francis William Fellowes (1896–1966)| chapter-url=http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A150167b.htm?hilite=lukis|location=Melbourne| publisher=[[Melbourne University Publishing|Melbourne University Press]]|isbn=|oclc=222721504}} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan (ed.)| year=1993| title=The RAAF in the Southwest Pacific Area 1942–1945|location=Canberra|publisher=RAAF Air Power Studies Centre|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/200/RAAF-History-Conference-1993-The-RAAF-in-the-SouthWest-Pacific-Area.aspx|isbn=0-642-19827-6}} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan|origyear=2001|year=2006| title=The Royal Australian Air Force: A History| location=London| publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0-19-555541-4}} *{{cite book|last=Thomson| first=Joyce| year=1991| title=The WAAAF in Wartime Australia| location=Melbourne| publisher= Melbourne University Press |isbn=0-522-84525-8}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-new|reason=Command formed from [[No. 9 Operational Group RAAF|No. 9 Operational Group]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Air Officer Commanding [[Northern Command (RAAF)|Northern Command]]|years=1944–1945}} {{s-aft|after=[[Allan Walters]]}} |- {{s-bef|before=[[Henry Wrigley]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Air Member for Personnel (Australia)|Air Member for Personnel]]|years=1942–1943}} {{s-aft|after=[[William Anderson (RAAF officer)|William
